    Head S (cont.) -

    Resumption of Debate on Question [16th March, 1998],

    "That the total sum to be allocated for Head S of the Main Estimates be reduced by $100." - [Mrs Yu-Foo Yee Shoon].



    Question again proposed.

    The Minister of State for Labour (Encik Othman bin Haron Eusofe): Sir, yesterday, the Member for Bukit Timah GRC, Mrs Yu-Foo Yee Shoon spoke about union membership. She has pointed out that with the changing educational profile of our workforce, the trade unions have found it increasingly difficult to recruit union members and to identify union leaders. She would like to find out how effective the Ministry's Guidelines on Determining the Eligibility of an Employee in Joining a Rank-and-File union.

    Sir, the Guidelines were formulated in consultation with the trade unions and employers in 1992. It was in response to unions' concern that the pool of employees eligible to join a trade union or remain as union members is declining. Sir, the unions felt that this trend would not only affect union membership but also reduce the talent pool for union leaders.

    Sir, I would like to inform the House that the Guidelines have been implemented smoothly. It has enabled the Ministry to examine the duties and responsibilities of middle management personnel and to determine whether there would be a conflict of interest if they were to be represented by a rank and file union. The smooth implementation of the Guidelines is reflected from the fact that the number of disputes involving union representation of middle management personnel has declined significantly over the years.

    Sir, in 1992, when the guidelines were first introduced, the Ministry received a

Column: 1409

total of 57 such cases. The figure has dropped substantially to 33 in 1993 and in the last four years, from 1994 to 1997, the number of disputes has further reduced to an average of about 10 cases a year. Sir, this trend, together with the fact that all disputes have been amicably resolved, clearly shows the Guidelines' effectiveness. It also indicates a positive change in employers' mindset to allow more of their middle management staff to join rank and file unions.

    Sir, I understand the concern of the Member that with an increasingly better educated workforce, more and more employees who are in executive positions may not be able to join trade unions and be represented in collective bargaining. However, with the introduction of the General Branch by the NTUC, employees in the executive and managerial positions could now join the unions as General Branch members although they will not be represented for collective bargaining purposes.

    Sir, Mrs Yu-Foo has advised those in the executive and managerial positions to seek the help of the Ministry if they have any grievances with their employers. Sir, they can always do so. And our conciliation officers have the necessary experience and are committed to do their best to assist them to work out amicable solutions with their employers.

    Sir, yesterday, Mr Cyrille Tan, Nominated MP, said that the conciliation officers must be capable with good command of labour laws and industrial practices. Sir, I would like to assure him that our conciliation officers have been given proper training and exposure and are well-grounded in labour laws and industrial relations practices. This would ensure that they are competent and effective in helping the disputing parties to resolve their differences amicably.

    Sir, we have also recently implemented an attachment scheme for our conciliation officers to work in NTUC on a short-term attachment to the NTUC Industrial Relations Department. This would provide

Column: 1410

them with an opportunity to develop close rapport and understanding with the union leaders as well as to sharpen their ability to deal with industrial relations issues. At the same time, NTUC has also sent their officers on short attachment to the Ministry of Labour's Industrial Relations Department. Sir, this arrangement enhances the ability of both union and Ministry officers to deal with industrial relations and personnel issues more effectively.

    Sir, on the issue of union leadership, while the talent pool may be reduced, as a result of a better educated workforce, there is now greater opportunity for better educated rank and file members and officials to upgrade themselves by attending courses at the Singapore Institute of Labour Studies (SILS). SILS was set up to develop and improve the quality of union leadership. And over the years, many grassroots union leaders have completed the Industrial Relations Diploma courses at SILS which cover the study of economics, industrial relations, human resource principles and labour laws. They are now equipped with the necessary knowledge and are in a better position to deal with labour-management issues and to be more effective in providing leadership. Sir, the Government will continue to support SILS in its efforts to upgrade union leadership and capability.

    Sir, in summary, I agree with the Member that unions add value to the human resource management process in a company. Particularly in this uncertain and difficult time, our unions can play a crucial role to help employers and workers cope with business downturn. Hence, apart from cases where there will be clear conflict of interest, there is no reason why employers should deny or resist the employees' desire to join unions.

    Sir, a dynamic and progressive trade union movement, able to galvanise workers in productive pursuit of skills upgrading and enhance competitiveness, is certainly a plus for Singapore and employers.

    The Minister for Labour (Dr Lee Boon Yang): Sir, yesterday, Mr Jeyaretnam

Column: 1411

spoke of workers losing their rights as a result of amendments to our labour laws in 1968. It is unfortunate that he is not here this morning to hear the response to his allegations. He spoke of the Lim Yew Hock era when, according to him, workers had rights. He waxed lyrical when referring to those days and perhaps, should I say, through the haze of time, the picture looks rather different.

    Sir, I feel obliged to complete the picture for hon. Members in this House. Mr Jeyaretnam forgot to tell Members that in the Lim Yew Hock era, workers faced great difficulties in getting jobs. Unemployment was very much higher than it is today. Workers who had jobs were paid poorly. They were indeed at the mercy of their employers. This was the case because, with so many unemployed people, employers could pick and choose. Workers and their families lived in squalid huts or over-crowded tenements. Many workers' children had to leave school early to help the family eke out a living. The economy was going nowhere. The future was bleak.

    Mr Jeyaretnam also forgot to inform this House that in those days, trade unions often took industrial actions without securing a mandate from their members, the workers, and without giving due regard to the viability of the company or the welfare of the workers. Trade unions also intervened in issues which should rightly be the management functions, such as hiring, promotion, transfer, dismissal and assignment of duties. The union's intervention had resulted in endless disputes leading to confrontation and strikes at the workplace. They did so because many unions had a political agenda and workers' rights and interests and welfare were the least of their concerns.

    Sir, the labour laws, prior to 1968, had inherent weaknesses that caused low productivity and inefficiency which were often subjected to abuse by workers and their unions. This was the era of highly adversarial and confrontational labour-management relations. There were more than 40 strikes a year paralysing trade, commerce and, indeed, the lives of

Column: 1412

ordinary citizens. In 1955 alone, there were 275 strikes resulting in the loss of almost 1 million man-days. The damage inflicted on the economy was devastating. The outcome of confrontational and adversarial labour-management relations was a poor investment climate, economic stagnation, unfavourable working conditions and terms, high unemployment and the bleak future for Singaporeans. It was for this reason that the labour laws were amended in 1968 to provide a more rational basis for industrial relations. The distinction was drawn between the functions of management and trade unions for balancing the interests of both parties. Thus, under the new provisions in the Industrial Relations Act, matters like promotion, transfer, hiring, right to retrench, dismissal and assignment of duties were excluded from collective bargaining between trade unions and employers. To prevent abuses by employers, the law enables workers and trade unions to seek redress through conciliation and adjudication including appeals against unfair dismissal.

    Sir, under the Employment Act introduced in 1968, the basic terms and conditions of employment as well as the rights of employees were rationalised. I must, however, point out that while employers were given the discretion to carry out fundamental management functions without being subjected to the process of collective bargaining, the rights of unions to take industrial action were not removed. These rights continue to be enshrined in the Trade Unions Act. The only difference is that a union which intends to take strike action must first obtain the consent and mandate of its members through a secret ballot. I would like to inform the House that the need to seek a mandate of members through secret ballot before an industrial action has also been introduced in countries like the United Kingdom and Australia. The requirement of the secret ballot is in line with democratic principle that such an extreme action must reflect the collective wishes of the members of the union.

    Sir, Mr Jeyaretnam has advocated a return to confrontation and adversarial labour-management relations. He fails to

Column: 1413

notice that many countries all over the world are trying hard to promote industrial harmony so that they could provide a favourable investment climate for economic growth and job creation. Would Mr Jeyaretnam like to see a return to the industrial strifes of the 50s that resulted in low productivity, economic stagnation, poor working conditions, low wages and high unemployment? When he called for the restoration of workers' and trade unions' rights in the 50s, does he realise that he is in fact setting the stage for abuses of rights and labour-management confrontation and job losses? On the other hand, the PAP Government's effort over the years resulted in close labour-management cooperation, discipline and higher productivity. This has helped us to attract high quality investments and better paying jobs for Singaporeans. Singapore has been enjoying full employment since the early 70s.
12.45 pm

    Sir, Mr Jeyaretnam also commented that there was a need to set up a tribunal with representatives from employers and trade unions. I find that strange. But then he has already admitted to this House that he does not read NTUC News. I know that he is not likely to read the Lianhe Zaobao. I am not sure if he reads the Straits Times and many other publications issued by the Government and even from my Ministry from time to time. Generally, I find that he is quite ill informed on many issues. If he had been more widely read or taken the trouble to research his topics that he wants to speak on, he would have discovered that such a tribunal already exists in our system. When a dispute, involving a trade union on the one hand and an employer on the other, cannot be resolved through conciliation, arbitration of the dispute would be heard by a tripartite panel, comprising representatives from the trade union and employers and presided over by a neutral third party who is a High Court Judge. This tripartite panel is our Industrial Arbitration Court.

    Mr Jeyaretnam says that he hardly heard of disputes being dealt with by the

Column: 1414

IAC, and then implies that the mechanism is not functioning properly since he has not heard of disputes being dealt with. The main reason for the lack of disputes and the low number of cases having to be referred to the IAC is the result of cooperation and amicable resolution of differences at every level. Because of responsible union leadership and enlightened management, most of the disputes had been settled amicably through discussion, either at the company level or conciliation at the Ministry of Labour. We should keep it this way.

    Sir, our ability to strike a fair and equitable balance between the interest of employers and workers within our legal framework has enabled Singapore to be consistently rated as one of the most attractive places for investments, and has often topped the world competitiveness ranking. Our favourable legal framework has also been a key factor in Singapore's workforce being regularly rated by BERI as number one in the world.

    Sir, let me take this opportunity to quickly explain to the House the dangers of over protective labour laws. The experience of many European countries has shown that over protective labour legislation has caused labour market rigidity, leading to unsustainable cost of doing business. They impede companies' efforts to restructure and upgrade their operations to meet new challenges. As companies are unable to operate efficiently, many of them had, over time, become uncompetitive. The end result is loss of jobs, economic stagnation and higher unemployment.

    Sir, an OECD study on unemployment in May 1994 concluded that employment protection legislation, which is designed to discourage dismissal by raising the cost of releasing workers, has made employers more reluctant to hire new workers. Many countries in Europe, which have particularly stringent or restrictive labour legislation, generally have a higher unemployment rate and employers frequently resort to temporary contract and other non-standard forms of employment to meet their needs for workers during times of market upturn.

Column: 1415



    The study made many recommendations. I will just quickly highlight three for Members' interest. (1) Wage and labour costs be made more flexible and that unnecessary restrictions be removed. (2) Employment security provisions that inhibit the expansion of employment in the private sector be reformed. (3) Unemployment and related benefit systems be restructured to achieve society's fundamental equity goal, such that - and this is important - the infringement of the efficient functioning of labour markets would be minimised.

    Sir, the OECD study and its recommendations clearly demonstrated that rigid and over protective labour legislation would undermine the efficient functioning of the labour market, stifle entrepreneurship and retard job creation. Hence, we must learn from their experience and avoid making the same mistakes.

    Sir, with the liberalisation of the world economy, global competition has intensified. We must therefore guard against the tendency to introduce protective and popular policies that will in fact introduce rigidity into our labour market and undermine our long-term competitiveness. Mr Jeyaretnam's question on workers' rights, therefore, sounds hollow and irrelevant. If workers had their rights removed unfairly, why did Mr Jeyaretnam, as leader of the Workers' Party, wait 30 years to raise this issue? The Workers' Party should have campaigned in every general election for the restoration of these so-called rights. Perhaps he knows in his heart the danger and foolishness of taking a course of action that can only lead to more disputes and upheaval.

    Dr Lily Neo (Kreta Ayer-Tanglin): Sir, on the "Gender Income Gap", the Department of Statistics in Singapore found that the ratio of female to male income declined from 73% in 1990 to 59% in 1995; that the income of the male workforce grew at a faster rate; that there were more males in the higher income groups and that there was a larger increase in the proportion of males with monthly incomes of $3,000 and above. All these

Column: 1416

indicate the significant widening in wage gap and career potential to the disadvantage of women in general.

    Why should this be so in Singapore? We are supposed to have equal opportunities, regardless of gender, in education and in career-seeking. And we have a system based on meritocracy. Why are the returns from investing in our female population not yielding the same accretion? Is there a shortfall in the contribution of our women to the economy as a result of this?

    The following are some areas that are worth looking into in this context.

    1. Human capital investment. Firms may anticipate a higher quit rate from women than men. As such, they may be cautious when it comes to investing in female employees for fear that they would not recover their investment. As a result of such forfeited career opportunities, women not only have loss of earnings but also loss in economic values within the society. Perhaps employers may adopt a new mindset with some sort of help.

    2. Double burden. There is a possibility that women may be more likely to shirk on the job than men. This might be the case because child-care responsibilities are more a distraction for women than men. Having children does impose workplace limitations on women. Perhaps we should look deeper at our child-caring facilities, namely, maids, grandparents, foster homes and child-care centres.

    3. Women's perception. Women are often subjected to socialisation as less able to handle risk-taking and as being less confident of their abilities. This could be a factor that plays a critical role in their expectations towards the salaries they deserve and therefore their perceptions towards the careers they choose. This factor may also result in the lesser demands by women when it comes to wage negotiations.

    4. Societal conditioning. The influence of societal conditioning as the source of occupational crowding towards a narrow set of "women's occupations" is worth looking at. Whether these "women occupations" are really worth so little that they

Column: 1417

usually command less lucrative rates on the whole ought to be studied. Are there stereotyping and bias amongst the policy-makers, teachers and counsellors that deter girls and women from advancing their education and entering the traditional male domains?

    5. Technological innovations. There is increasing stress towards higher value-added activities. New-age technology that points towards the ascendancy of electronics and computer-related industries may require people with strong background in mathematics. This is an area which is traditionally the stronghold of men. Are Singaporean women more likely to shun these "high-tech" occupations by choice or by preference? Do we need to change this mindset?

    6. Reproductive role. To fulfil this role, women are required, at one time or another, to consider discontinuity and subsequent reintegration in their jobs. Effectively, they are prevented from full integration at their jobs. The resultant effect is that they renounce their ambitions and resign themselves to those lesser employment prospects than what their qualification would warrant.

    Sir, it should be a worthwhile exercise to study and ascertain these elements within the Singapore context. I would like to suggest that the Ministry of Manpower do this and help us overcome some of our shortcomings and enable the Singapore woman realise her true and rightful place in the Singapore economy.

    Mr Inderjit Singh (Ang Mo Kio): Sir, in this cut, I was originally going to ask the Minister for Manpower to help reduce the cost of hiring skilled foreign workers, basically the foreign worker levy to $100. I am glad to note that I was pre-empted and the Minister has announced that this is going to happen very soon.

    I am sure this will go a long way in helping the manufacturing and service sectors reduce the labour-related cost. I hope that this will apply to foreign workers of all nationalities and not restricted to certain nationalities only.

Column: 1418

However, I would like to still ask the Minister to consider some temporary measures for all existing foreign workers, including unskilled workers. This request is to help companies get through the tough times expected in the next two years or so. I would like to suggest that the Minister consider temporarily reducing the levy for all foreign workers to $100 for the next 1-2 years. And with the understanding that it would be raised to the original levels once things stabilise in our economy. I am sure this will help our businesses survive the tough time in the next few years.

    Mr Goh Choon Kang (Marine Parade): Sir, I would like to address the problem of run away foreign workers and foreign maids. I would like to suggest imposing a security bond on all foreign workers and foreign maids, as one way to tackle the problem of run away foreign workers and missing maids.

    Sir, yesterday, the Minister for Home Affairs announced that such a security bond would be imposed on foreign workers from two foreign countries. I see no reason why this should not apply to foreign workers and maids from other countries.

    Alternatively, I would suggest that the foreign workers and foreign maids can be asked to contribute 20% of their monthly income to a foreign labour fund to be administered by the Manpower Ministry. This is to make all foreign workers themselves responsible for their good behaviour while in Singapore. Upon completion of their contract in Singapore or upon the cancellation of their work permit, their contribution will then be returned to them when they pack up and go home, perhaps with some interest earned, similar to the CPF fund.

    The foreign labour fund can be deemed as some kind of a good behaviour bond. By running away or committing serious offences, foreign workers would put their foreign labour fund savings in jeopardy. This could deter many from misbehaving while in Singapore.

    Secondly, irregardless of whether an employer is at fault when a work permit

Column: 1419

holder goes missing and cannot be traced, the security bond of the employer is forfeited. I would like to suggest that in cases where it can be established that an employer is not at fault, then the security bond or deposit should not be forfeited. Of course, the burden of proof should be on the employer.
1.00 pm

    Mr Ahmad Mohd Magad (Pasir Ris): Sir, still on the issue of foreign maids. The Ministry of Labour announced in November last year that the foreign domestic worker levy would go up by $15 a month with effect from 1st April 1998, ie, next month. This is to be followed by small annual revisions thereafter. The objective of the foreign domestic worker levy, according to the Ministry, is to regulate demand for foreign domestic workers, and to discourage Singaporeans from becoming overly reliant on them.

    Sir, a working couple trying to juggle between babies, housework, career and upgrading their skills and studies are already finding their lives very stressful. Thus, it would appear to me that even if the Government continues to raise the foreign domestic worker levy, the demand will remain fairly inelastic. For those in this category having a maid is really not an option. The concern over the levy increase lies not only in the higher costs to households, especially for young working couples, but more importantly, the availability of alternatives such as childcare centres. There are also those who are in need of a maid to look after their beloved elderly while they are at work. Having a maid for this group is a necessity.

    The Government must not be seen to be sending confusing signals. If Singapore wants its women to come forward to contribute economically, then there must be assurance that their children are not deprived of proper and dedicated care. The question then is how the Ministry could ensure that the measures taken to increase the maid levy really meet its objective in terms of controlling the numbers while at the same time ensuring that those really in need of a maid service are not deprived. In the wake of the

Column: 1420

current economic downturn, will the Minister reconsider deferring the increase of the foreign domestic worker levy until the situation improves, as it may adversely impact those who are affected by the current economic conditions, but at the same time are still dependent on the services of foreign domestic maids.

    The Chairman: I have to remind Members that the "guillotine" time is at 1.55 pm and we seem to have still quite a long list of speakers. Mr Chuang.

    Mr Chuang Shaw Peng (Nominated Member)(In Mandarin): First, I would like to declare my interest as a Director of a construction company. However, I have no pecuniary interest in the subject matter that I will be speaking on.

    In Singapore, more than 90% of the workers in the construction industry are foreign workers. At present, an employer has to pay foreign worker levy to the Government at $200 for each skilled worker and $440 for each unskilled worker. The difference of $240 is to encourage the employers to engage more skilled workers in order to improve productivity in the construction industry. This policy is correct and encouraging.

    The construction industry is a very competitive industry. Since the Government's announcement of the adjustment to the foreign worker levy at the end of last year, many construction companies have been trying very hard to secure more skilled workers to replace the unskilled workers, in order to cut cost.

    At the present moment, the Singapore Government's Construction Industry Training School has been flooded with applications from many construction companies for their workers to be trained and to sit for the skills certification examination. The response was so overwhelming that the school is finding it difficult to cope. Obviously, this strategy to actively encourage the workers to increase their skill level is like "sending burning charcoal in a snowing weather". It is a timely help to the industry, and is significantly effective.

    Furthermore, the original purpose of the foreign workers levy is to increase the cost

Column: 1421

of employing foreign workers so as to prevent the employers from employing cheap foreign workers to replace the more expensive local workers. However, after years of implementation of this policy, and the levy being raised year after year, the number of local workers entering the construction industry has not increased, but has actually reduced. Even the supervisory-level work, which was formerly dominated by Singaporeans, is now gradually taken over by engineers employed from foreign countries.

    Apparently, construction work has not much attraction for Singaporeans. Unless the Government thoroughly changes its policy, like last year's large-scale incentives for the employers to employ skilled workers, it will not be easy to change the local workers' present attitude of fighting shy of the construction industry. At the same time, the levy for unskilled workers will be raised to $470 with effect from 1st April. Other than increasing the construction cost, it will not have much encouraging effect.

    I believe that when the Government was formulating this policy it was considering the need to attain budget neutrality. However, from 1st April onwards, when the new rates take effect, so long as the number of skilled workers is lower than 15% of the total number of construction workers, the Government's income in foreign worker levy will be increased, and not neutral. According to the statistics of the Construction Industry Development Board (CIDB), at the moment, skilled foreign workers who are paying the foreign worker levy account for approximately 10% of the total number of foreign construction workers in Singapore. Since the new policy on foreign worker levy was announced at the end of last year, and although the Singapore Construction Industry Training School has increased the number of its courses, it will be impossible to rapidly raise the percentage within a short period of time. In any event, so long as the Government's income is increased, then the wool must still come from the back of the sheep - the cost in the property sector will surely go up.

Column: 1422



    At this present economic turmoil where business is bad, all the trades and industries are asking for reduction in taxes and rents, and the construction industry is also hoping for some concessions. All these years, the Government has been collecting more than $100 million a year from the foreign workers levy. However, there are more and more foreign workers coming to Singapore. This merely indicates an increase in the Government's revenue from the foreign worker levy, and not the best plan to improve productivity. To afford the increased expenditure, individuals need to have more cash and hence need higher wages. For individuals, they have to pay a higher price to own or rent a property. To be able to afford these higher prices, they need higher wages, so the total wage costs go up. This creates a direct impact on the cost of doing business in Singapore.
